expanded_description: Graphs provide a visual representation of linear relationships. Learning to read equations from graphs is a fundamental skill that connects the visual and algebraic worlds. By identifying key features like the y-intercept and slope, we can write the equation of any line shown on a coordinate plane.

core_concept.principle: To write the equation of a line from its graph: (1) Identify the y-intercept $b$ (where the line crosses the y-axis). (2) Find the slope $m$ by counting rise and run between two points on the line. (3) Write the equation in slope-intercept form: $y = mx + b$. If the line is vertical or horizontal, use the special forms $x = a$ or $y = b$.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a graph as a picture of an equation. The y-intercept is where the story starts—where the line meets the y-axis. The slope tells you how the story progresses—how much y changes for each step in x. By reading these two features, you can write the complete story as an equation.

sections.section_title: 5.1.1 Identifying the Y-Intercept from a Graph
sections.introduction: The y-intercept is the point where the line crosses the y-axis. It's always at $(0, b)$ and gives us the starting value in our equation.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.1.2: Identifying y-intercepts on different lines.

key_concept.definition: The y-intercept $b$ is the y-coordinate of the point where the line crosses the y-axis. Since every point on the y-axis has $x = 0$, the y-intercept is always $(0, b)$. To find it from a graph, locate where the line meets the y-axis and read the y-coordinate.
key_concept.context: The y-intercept often represents a starting value in real-world contexts: initial distance, fixed cost, beginning population. Getting it right is crucial for accurate equations.

image.caption: Figure 5.1.3: Reading y-intercepts from graphs.

sections.introduction: Slope measures the steepness of a line. On a graph, we can find it by counting rise and run between two points.

introduction_image.alt: Line with rise and run marked
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.1.10: Finding slope by counting rise and run.

key_concept.definition: To find slope from a graph, select two points on the line where the line passes through grid intersections. Count the vertical change (rise) and horizontal change (run) between them. Slope $m = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}}$. Rise is positive if moving up, negative if moving down. Run is always positive when moving right.
key_concept.context: This method is often more intuitive than using the slope formula when you have a clear graph. Choose points that make counting easy.

image.alt: Counting rise and run between two points on a line
image.caption: Figure 5.1.11: Rise = 4, run = 2, slope = 2.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Slope = rise/run. Count carefully, noting direction (up = positive rise, down = negative).

sections.introduction: Once we have the y-intercept and slope, we can write the equation in slope-intercept form $y = mx + b$.

introduction_image.alt: Graph with y-intercept and slope labeled
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.1.18: Using y-intercept and slope to write equation.

key_concept.definition: To write the equation of a line from its graph in slope-intercept form: (1) Find the y-intercept $b$ (where line crosses y-axis). (2) Find the slope $m$ by counting rise/run. (3) Substitute into $y = mx + b$.
key_concept.context: This is the most common method for writing equations from graphs because slope-intercept form directly shows both key features.

worked_examples.title: Writing Equations from Graphs

image.caption: Figure 5.1.20: Write the equation of each line.

worked_examples.problem: Write the equation of each line in slope-intercept form.

step_by_step.explanation: Y-intercept at (0,2). From (0,2) to (3,4): rise = 2, run = 3, so $m = \frac{2}{3}$
Y-intercept at (0,-3). From (0,-3) to (2,1): rise = 4, run = 2, so $m = 2$
Y-intercept at (0,4). From (0,4) to (3,1): rise = -3, run = 3, so $m = -1$
Y-intercept at (0,0). From (0,0) to (4,2): rise = 2, run = 4, so $m = \frac{1}{2}$

process_flow.description: Locate where the line crosses the y-axis. This point is $(0, b)$. Record $b$.
process_flow.mechanism: Look for intersection with vertical axis.

process_flow.description: Choose two points on the line that pass through grid intersections. Count rise and run.
process_flow.mechanism: Rise = vertical change (up positive, down negative). Run = horizontal change (always positive right).

sections.section_title: 5.1.4 Using Two Points from the Graph
sections.introduction: Sometimes the y-intercept is not clearly visible or not an integer. In such cases, we can use any two points on the line to find the equation.

introduction_image.alt: Line with two points marked, y-intercept not visible
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.1.29: Using two points when y-intercept isn't clear.

key_concept.definition: If the y-intercept is not easily readable from the graph, select two points on the line with integer coordinates. Calculate slope using $m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}$, then use point-slope form $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$ to write the equation, and simplify to slope-intercept form if desired.
key_concept.context: This method works for any line, regardless of whether the y-intercept is visible. It's a reliable backup when the intercept method is difficult.

sections.section_title: 5.1.5 Horizontal and Vertical Lines from Graphs
sections.introduction: Horizontal and vertical lines are special cases that require different equation forms.

introduction_image.alt: Horizontal and vertical lines on graphs
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.1.34: Special cases: horizontal and vertical lines.

key_concept.definition: A horizontal line has equation $y = b$, where $b$ is the y-coordinate of every point. Its slope is $0$. A vertical line has equation $x = a$, where $a$ is the x-coordinate of every point. Its slope is undefined.
key_concept.context: Recognizing these special cases prevents us from trying to find a slope that doesn't exist (for vertical lines) or using the wrong form.

sections.introduction: Real-world graphs often come from data or measurements. Writing equations from them allows us to model and predict.

key_concept.definition: When given a real-world graph, the axes have units and meaning. The y-intercept represents the initial value, and the slope represents the rate of change. The equation must include these contextual meanings.
key_concept.context: This skill transforms visual data into mathematical models that can be used for prediction and analysis.

worked_examples.title: Distance-Time Graph to Equation

image.alt: Distance-time graph for a car trip
image.caption: Figure 5.1.40: Write equation for distance vs time.

worked_examples.problem:
The graph shows a car's distance from home over time. The line passes through (0,0) and (4,240). Time is in hours, distance in miles.
a) Find the slope and interpret it.
b) Find the y-intercept and interpret it.
c) Write the equation relating distance and time.
worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Slope = 60 mph (speed)
b) Y-intercept = 0 (starting at home)
c) $d = 60t$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world graphs: slope has units (miles/hour), intercept has real meaning.

worked_examples.title: Cost-Quantity Graph
worked_examples.problem:
A graph shows total cost vs number of items. The line passes through (0,200) and (50,600). Cost is in dollars, quantity in items.
a) Find and interpret the slope.
b) Find and interpret the y-intercept.
c) Write the cost equation.
worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Slope = $\$8$/item (cost per item)
b) Y-intercept = $\$200$ (fixed costs)
c) $C(x) = 8x + 200$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Business graphs: slope = unit cost, intercept = fixed costs.

sections.section_title: 5.1.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when writing equations from graphs. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Reading the x-coordinate instead of y-coordinate.
characteristics: Writing (3,0) as y-intercept when line crosses at (0,3)
classifications.behavior: Wrong intercept leads to wrong equation.

examples.process: Error: For line through (0,3), saying y-intercept is 3? Actually that's correct. Better error: Saying y-intercept is (3,0)

classifications.value: Getting sign of slope wrong when counting.

image.alt: Line going down but counted as up
image.caption: Figure 5.1.44: Error - wrong slope sign.

examples.process: Error: For line from (0,4) to (3,1), counting rise as 3 instead of -3

classifications.value: Trying to find slope for vertical lines.
characteristics: Attempting to calculate slope for x = constant
Writing vertical line as y = something
classifications.behavior: Undefined slope treated as number, wrong equation.

examples.process: Error: For vertical line x = 3, writing y = 3

worked_examples.title: Correcting Graph-to-Equation Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student looked at a line through (0,2) and (4,0) and wrote $y = \frac{1}{2}x + 2$. Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Line crosses at (0,2), so b = 2 is correct
From (0,2) to (4,0): rise = -2, run = 4, so slope = -2/4 = -1/2

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct equation: $y = -\frac{1}{2}x + 2$. Error was sign of slope.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Check direction: line going down has negative slope.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to write equations from a variety of graphs.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of each line in slope-intercept form:
1) Line through (0,3) and (5,5)
2) Line through (0,-2) and (4,0)
3) Line through (-1,4) and (3,-4)
4) Horizontal line through (2,5)
5) Vertical line through (-3,2)
6) Line with y-intercept 4 and slope -2/3

step_by_step.explanation: No clear y-intercept, use two points: $m = \frac{-4-4}{3-(-1)} = \frac{-8}{4} = -2$

summary: Writing equations from graphs involves identifying key features of the line. The y-intercept $b$ is found where the line crosses the y-axis at $(0, b)$. The slope $m$ is found by counting rise and run between two points on the line: $m = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}}$. Once $m$ and $b$ are known, the equation can be written in slope-intercept form $y = mx + b$. If the y-intercept is not clearly visible, use any two points on the line to calculate slope, then use point-slope form to find the equation. Horizontal lines have the form $y = b$ (slope 0), and vertical lines have the form $x = a$ (undefined slope). In real-world applications, the slope represents the rate of change with appropriate units, and the y-intercept represents the initial value. This skill connects visual representations to algebraic equations, enabling mathematical modeling of real situations.
